title.narrative: 00060927: Building capacity to eliminate Persistent Organic Pollutants pesticides stockpiles in Vietnam Mid Term Evaluation Report

description.narrative: The project is to remove capacity barriers to the sustainable elimination of POPs (Persistent Organic Pollutants) Pesticides in Vietnam.
capital of a political entity

1. The number of sites cleaned 2. Volumes of POP pesticides or conterminated soil treated . 3. Compliance with international standards for pesticide stockpiles management 4. Government budget allocations adequate to destroy stockpiles and to manage contaminated sites in future

comment.narrative: 1) According to MONRE data in 2010, there are more than 1000 contaminated sites in Vietnam that have potential adverse impact to people leaving around the sites. Foods produced from the high concentrated POP pesticide sites once taken by people will effect the health of those people. 2) 0 tones treated 3) There are no standards and guidance for management and destruction of POP pesticide in 2010, which local people and authority is not well aware of risks to their life and treatment methods. 4) The Government expenditure for this activities in 2006 is rather modest with an amount of USD 382,000

1) Clean at least 1 additional site 2) Further collect and treat additional 170 tones high Pop pesticides contaminated soil 3) (i) Capacity building/Continue training to ensure soil collection, treatment, management and monitoring in accordance with international standard (ii) Carry out non-combustion technology pilot and share information with provinces 4) More than US$ 10 million allocated from Govt budget

1) Two more contaminated sites cleaned in Nghe An Province 2) Further collected 281 tone and treated additional 340.5 tones POP pesticides stockpile and contaminated soil 3) (i) 279 people trained in 7 courses in 2015; (ii) Three non-combustion technology tested 4) Approximately US$ 14 millions co-financing of Govt in 5 years project implementation

description.narrative: To remove capacity barriers to the sustainable elimination of POPs pesticides in Vietnam
Number of sites posing threat to human health

comment.narrative: At least 600 sites with known or potential adverse human health impacts and risk for the environment

By the end of the project at least 1140 tons of POPs waste is destructed and the sites where the pesticides are removed for disposal are rehabilitated, acute risks to human health and the environment are eliminated and potential and latent risk are respectively re-mediated on the mid term and contained for the long term. For these sites a aftercare and monitoring program is available. By the end of the project the project Team is trained and has experiences in managing such rehabilitation POPs pesticides project and more than one destruction company is able to destruct POPs pesticides in Vietnam.

1. As of 30 June 2015, total POPs pesticides waste and stockpiles destroyed by the project was approximately 720 tons. Of which, around 488 tons were collected in Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces and destroyed at Holcim during this reporting period.
2. In this reporting period, through the National Target Program for Pollution Mitigation and Environment improvement (NTP-PMEI) and 1946 Program, the Government budget was provided to carry out remediation activities at 20 sites with a total budget of approximately 194 billion VND (equivalent to approximately 8.7 million USD).
Local Governments also provided 420 million VND (equivalent to 19,000 USD) for excavating, packaging and local transportation of 67.9 tons of contaminated soil at the Tan Long, Tan Phu and Hung Khanh sites, which were treated at Holcim using funding from the GEF project budget.

description.narrative: Improved capacity facilitates elimination of POPs pesticides stockpiles
International standards met in management of pesticide stockpiles.

comment.narrative: There is no standards and guideline for management and destruction of POPs pesticides.
International standards will be adopted for management and treatment of POP pesticide stockpiles and POP pesticide contaminated sites.

The revision of the Technical Guidelines on Environmental Management of POPs Pesticide Contaminated Sites (formerly called EMP) was completed after user-testing and final consultation in 2014. One thousand five hundred (1,500) copies of the guideline were printed, distributed during training courses and to provincial Departments of Natural Resources and Environment (DONREs).

description.narrative: Government allocates adequate budget to destroy stockpiles and manage contaminated sites

comment.narrative: From 2008 onwards, Government expenditure for destruction of POPs pesticides is at least $600,000 /year (until stockpiles destroyed)

In this reporting period 2014-2015, Government budget was provided to carry out remediation activities at 20 sites with a total budget of approximately 194 billions VND (equivalent to approximately 8.7 million USD).
Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces also provided 420 million VNDs (equivalent to 19,000 USD) for excavating, packaging and local transportation of 67.9 tons of contaminated soil at the Tan Long, Tan Phu and Hung Khanh sites, which were treated at Holcim using funding from the GEF project budget.

description.narrative: Existence of potential qualified and licensed National and International companies besides Holcim

comment.narrative: Not aware of more than one National qualified company. International qualified companies are known

Eliminate the monopoly position of Holcim in the POP treatment market in Vietnam. National and local Government know better/more about treatment & technology suppliers, both internationally & nationally.

Field pilots for three (3) non-combustion technologies for soil decontamination are on-going using (1) Daramend technology; (2) Nano Iron soil treatment; and (3) Soil washing. The field pilots are expected to be completed by Sept-Oct 2015 and the results will be incorporated in the technology handbook that is being drafted on available and relevant technologies for soil remediation. That handbook would help provinces seeking appropriate technologies.

description.narrative: Expression of interest received from potential qualified and licensed National and International companies

comment.narrative: Potential qualified and licensed national and International companies are not aware of the upcoming site rehabilitation project including POPs pesticide destruction. Project Team is not aware if potential qualified and licensed National and International companies have interest in this site rehabilitation project including POPs pesticide destruction.
Potential qualified and licensed National and International companies are well informed and participated in the bidding of treatment packages by the project and by Government budget.

Compared to the beginning of the project, national and local Governments have a better knowledge on available and suitable treatment technologies as well as existing technology suppliers in this market. Technology suppliers, both national and international, are better informed through e-mails and UNDP website of decontamination and disposal opportunities. This was confirmed by the large number of companies participating in the international bidding procedures, which took place during the previous reporting period. Therefore, Holcim no longer holds a monopoly position in this market in Viet Nam.

description.narrative: Data sheets/database of contaminated sites is set up. The database is user-friendly that easy for uploading data and extracting information

comment.narrative: Four different inventories are made using four different data formats. The data vary in level of details and quality. In total 1153 site have are recorded and most likely less than half of the site is visited for an inventory. Information on the site data sheet varies from only a site name to detailed assessments. These data are partly entered in two different data sets with a different set up
Database of contaminated sites is available and ready for use
The contaminated sites database is publicly available at caithienmoitruong.vea.gov.vn:9000/. Final adjustments and corrections will be completed by June-July 2015.

description.narrative: A data of priority sites, which need treatment, is made available to the relevant stakeholders and authorities. The data contains relevant and reliable information for identifying environmental and human health risks and for making site clean-up plans.

comment.narrative: Around 500 sites are being prioritized for treatment based on the Cir 07 and Article 92. Treatment priority of contaminated sites are catergorised based on level of concentration in the soil and not yet based on the risks/risk assessment report.
Risk assessment is done for prioritized sites that selected and will be treated by project budget
Completed in the 2012-2013 reporting period. During this reporting period, local governments started applying the risk assessment method to contaminated sites in their respective provinces.

description.narrative: Clear technical guideline that can improve the quality of standard rehabilitation plan including budget and time planning for each POPs pesticide site category.

comment.narrative: Guidelines by MOSTE in 1999 for pesticides destruction are obsolete pesticides and not appropriate for POPs Pesticides. No guideline for properly making preliminary risk assessment and identifying potential and latent risks
Appropriated technical guideline and SOP are available
1500 copies of the Technical Guidelines (formerly EMP) were printed, distributed during trainings and sent by mail to provincial DONREs.

description.narrative: Experienced trainer(s) with CV details are recruited to deliver training for government staff on POPs pesticides site cleanup

comment.narrative: Lack of knowledge on POPs pesticides site clean-up
A competent trainer is contracted and delivered good training course to Government staff

This activity was completed during the previous reporting period. The training task has been included in the Visiting Technical Advisor's ToR. The Visiting Technical Advisor was recruited in 2013. Before that, training was part of Tauw contract.

description.narrative: Number of Trainees that participated in trainings and obtained certificates

comment.narrative: Very limited number of government agencies have sufficient knowledge on contaminated site management, monitoring, disposal facilities, soil survey and soil insitu, onsite remediation

Staff of government agencies are trained in appropriate technologies and application of standards and guidelines for site assessment including topsoil survey. Project Team and PM are also equipped to manage site cleanup campaigns.

Five (5) training courses on the use and application of the Technical Guideline on Environmental Management of POPs Pesticides Contaminated Sites were conducted during this reporting period in Quang Binh (Sep 2014), Nghe An (Oct 2014), Nam Dinh (Mar 2015), Nghe An (Mar 2015) and Quang Ninh (Apr 2015).
One Sampling and Mapping Training was also conducted in Nam Dinh (June 2015).
The total number of staff trained during this reporting period was 265, of which 70% were from provinces.

description.narrative: Contribution (study, comment paper ...) to the legal policy and framework through legal document revision and development.

comment.narrative: National legal policy and framework at the project design are not adequate for management and treatment of POPs pesticides contaminated sites
Technical contributions is delivered to the Government, Institutionalised, applied and appreciated by MONRE

-The project provided technical comments/inputs to the revision of Law on Environment Protection (LEP) which was approved in late June 2014. It was the first time LEP mentioned the need of applying a risk-based approach for assessing and managing contaminated sites, including POPs pesticides contaminated sites.
- The new technical standard (QCVN 54) on Treatment Threshold for Different Type of Land Use, developed with support of the project in 2013, appears to have important economic implications as in certain cases it can actually reduce the economic burden on national and local budget for the treatment of contaminated sites.
- For example, if the contaminated site is not planned for living or agricultural activities, it is unnecessary to treat contaminated soil to a POPs concentration level lower than 1.7 ppm. This can save money for national and local budget.

comment.narrative: There is no monitoringg plan for contaminated sites. No guideline or regulation state that it is neccessary.
Participatory monitoring plan following international standards is developed and translated to Vietnamese
Aftercare and monitoring plans have been updated in English for 3 sites (Mau 2, Thach Luu and Hon Tro), and were subsequently translated into Vietnamese for handover to local authorities.

description.narrative: At least 7 sites with 1000 tons of highly contaminated POPs waste/stockpiles will be treated, impact on human health relieved.

- Number of tons of POPs pesticides waste and stockpile destructed/treated
- Number of sites applied clean up & treatment measures
- Evaluation site reports, aftercare and monitoring results confirm the successful of treatment

comment.narrative: Stockpiles slowly destroyed and buried pesticides continuing forming a environmental problem by not applying International standards

By the end of 2015, 1,140 tons of POPs pesticides will have been destroyed; mid and long term measures implemented to control and contain potential and latent risks at the sites where pesticides are removed.

1. As of 30 June 2015, total POPs pesticides waste and stockpiles destroyed by the project was approximately 720 tons. Of which, around 488 tons were collected in Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces and destroyed at Holcim during this reporting period.
2. Isolation measures/rehabilitation activities for 2 sites (Hon Tro and Thach luu) were completed in Aug 2014.
3. Field pilot for three (3) non-combustion technologies is on-going. Around 60-80 tons of POPs pesticides contaminated soil (500-3000 ppm) are being pilot-treated by non-combustion technologies using (1) Daramend technology; (2) Nano Iron soil treatment; and (3) Soil washing. The field pilots are expected to be completed by Sept-Oct 2015.

description.narrative: Number of companies performing a test for obtaining license

comment.narrative: Only Holicm has the license to handle and destruct POPs pesticides at the begining of the project that made them as a monopoly supplier in the market in Viet Nam
After two years from the project start, the test and assessment for obtaining license to handle and destruct POPs pesticides completed.

This project activity was completed in 2012. In addition to Holcim, Thanh Cong cement in the northern part of Viet Nam also obtained a license to handle and destruct POPs pesticides at the beginning of 2013.
No further activities are anticipated because the international bidding for POPs pesticides waste treatment conducted under the project in 2013 also put a stop to the monopoly position of Holcim.

description.narrative: Acute risks at selected priority sites are eliminated by removing POPs pesticide waste from the site

comment.narrative:
At the beginning of the project, treatment methods to eliminate acute risks at selected priority sites was not started yet.
The priority list of contaminated sites identified more than 1,000 POPs pesticides contaminated sites in Viet Nam, 7 sites were selected for applying treatment methods from the project budget. Detail information on contamination levels of selected sites are available for determining volume of contaminated soil from 700-880 tons instead of 1,000 tons at project design. Of which, pilot 25 tons of contaminated soil in Thai Nguyen was disposed/excavated and treated at Holcim in 2011 .
At the end of the project, objectives for the POPs pesticides waste and stockpile treatment and management completed.

1. By 30 June 2015, the total POPs pesticides wastes and stockpiles destroyed by project was around 720 tons.
Of this amount, during this reporting period ~ 488 tons were collected in Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces and destroyed at Holcim as follows:
- Around 145 tons of POPs pesticides wastes and stockpiles was collected from 3 sites in Ha Tinh (Thach Luu, Thach Huong, Son Tho) in July 2014 and was destructed at Holcim in Sept - Oct 2014
-Collection and destruction of 216 tons of POPs pesticides waste and stockpiles from the Hon Tro site were completed in September 2014.
- Collection and destruction of 59.5 tons of POPs pesticides waste and stockpiles from Chien Thang were completed in December 2014.
- Collection and destruction of 67.9 tons of POPs pesticides waste and stockpiles from the Tan Long and Tan Phu sites were completed in January 2015.
2. Isolation measures/rehabilitation activities for the for Hon Tro and Thach Luu sites were completed in August 2014.
3. Field pilots for three (3) non-combustion technologies are on-going. Around 60-80 tons of POPs pesticides contaminated soil (500-3000 ppm) are being pilot-treated by non-combustion technologies.

description.narrative:
-Number of site applying isolation measures/ rehabilitation activities.
-Environment Management Plan (EMP) completed and approved.

comment.narrative: There is no isolation measures/rehabilitation activities to reducing and containing potential and latent risks of contaminated sites.
At the end of the project, potential and latent risks are reduced and/or contained and aftercare and monitoring program is delivered for the selected priority sites.

Three (3) sites (Hon Tro, Mau 2, Thach Luu) applied isolation measures/rehabilitation activities during this reporting period.
Environmental Management Plans (EMPs) were separated into 5 phases for the sites. Previous versions of EMP were designed as an “all in one” document.

description.narrative:
-Handover documents to local authority are signed and local competent staff is trained
-Technical tools are available for POPs waste treatment and contaminated site management

comment.narrative:
-Responsibilities are not allocated
- National Target Program on Pollution Mitigation and Environment Improvement (NTP–PMEI) approved in 2012 with its 2nd component dealing with 247 high pesticides concentration sites.
- A number of technical barriers existed for smooth implementation of Decision No. 1946 and NTP-PMEI (shortage of information and data on contaminated sites, no guidance on relevant technologies to local authority, uniform template and format, etc.).
- Some provinces with high number of sites are facing difficulty in managing pesticides contaminated sites
At the end of the project, mid and long term actions allocated for the coming 10 years and implemented

1. The Thach Luu hand-over document for the local authorities (including EMP) will be signed in July 2015.
2. M&E indicators for the monitoring and reporting of the management and treatment of POPs pesticides contaminated sites were drafted in May 2015.
3. The database containing information on POPs pesticide contaminated sites is publicly available on-line at caithienmoitruong.vea.gov.vn:9000/.
The database allows data update by provinces. The data can be consolidated nation-wide and is managed at the national level. Final adjustments and corrections of the database will be completed in July 2015.
4. Handbook for the introduction of non-combustion techniques for contaminated sites targeting local authorities has been drafted.
5. As a pilot exercise the project designed a Provincial Plan for the Sustainable Management of Pesticides-contaminated sites for Nghe An province, which has hundreds of contaminated sites. The plan applies land-use purpose approaches and encourages public-private partnerships. The start of plan preparation took place in Nghe An from 22 to 23 June 2015.

description.narrative: Improved chemicals management prevents importation and use of POPs pesticides

Volumes of pesticides illegally imported
Number of staff and related stakeholders trained or received necessary information

comment.narrative: At least 10 tonnes per month
By the end of the project, the volumes of illegal pesticides confiscated are no more than 2 tonnes per month (based on equal level of effort)

According to the Customs newspaper in 2014, 100 litres of illegal herbicides and 2-3 tons of wet powder were confiscated in the border provinces during the first half of 2014.
The Customs officers had already been trained in the previous reporting period.

description.narrative: Adoption of national chemical safety standards

comment.narrative:
The Law on Chemistry passed in 2007. The Decree 108/2008/ND-CP adopted in 2008. Circular 28/2010/TT-BCT adopted in 2010.
- Law on Environment Protection (LEP) was revised and approved in 2014 and entered into force in June 2015. Guidelines for the LEP implementation is needed.

-Policy and legal framework for management of POPs pesticides and POPs pesticides contaminated sites improved and upgraded. 01 draft circular on guidance for classification of contaminated site completed
Draft study on the classification of contaminated sites was submitted as an input for drafting a circular on management of contaminated sites (to be approved in September 2015).

description.narrative: Number of training courses completed and number of participants

comment.narrative: Almost no training in management of POPs pesticides or related issues.
By the end of 2015 staff of all line agencies trained in management of POPs pesticides and related issues

- Five (5) EMP Training courses were carried out in Quang Binh (Sep 2014), Nghe An (Oct 2014), Nam Dinh (Mar 2015), Nghe An (Mar 2015), Quang Ninh (Apr 2015). One (1) Sampling and Mapping training course was done in Nam Dinh (June 2015) for Northern provincial staff.
Two (2) more training courses on Sampling and Mapping for Central and Southern provinces are expected to take place in August 2015.
Total participants trained in this reporting period was 265. Participants come from relevant national and provincial departments.

By the end of 2011 a compendium of legal documents on POPs pesticides management has been consolidated and disseminated to all Customs offices at provinces
All activities were completed in 2012. No further activities to report on.

description.narrative: Number of store/facilities applying the standard criteria and design

comment.narrative: There are a number of storage that contain confiscated illegal trading pesticides and chemicals for a long time without proper risk management measures that can be leakages and become contaminated sites, such as the 20m3 storage at Lang Son provinces.
By the end of 2015, storage facilities of at least 50 m3 with proper risk management measures built at five or more key sites

One (1) storage facility in Lao Cai province and one (1) storage facility in Binh Thuan provinces were repaired and upgraded by the project to meet the standard design criteria for POPs storage facilities.

description.narrative: Standard criteria and design for storage completed

comment.narrative: No clear standard and guideline
Standard design for storages that contain confiscated pesticides due to illegally trading completed and introduced to provinces
The final revision of the Standard Design for Storage Facilities was completed in March 2015. Subsequently it will be printed and disseminated to provinces.

description.narrative: 1) One time-series tool called 'the Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI)' established to measure local government performance in Viet Nam. PAPI is a rigorous policy tool that monitors and measures the performance of governance and public administration of all 63 provinces in Viet Nam based on citizens’ experiences. (PAPI is part of outputs 3.3.1 and 3.3.4 of One UN Plan) 2) Number of provinces responding to PAPI findings by seeking measures to improve their performance over time 3) Number of in-depth research conducted to bring insights into why public polices do not work and how to make them work better for the benefit of citizens

comment.narrative: 1) (Baseline 2009) No available tool that provides data to track changes in local governance and public administration reforms in Viet Nam from citizens' perspectives and experiences; no available monitoring and evaluation system to measure the effectiveness and efficiency of international development partners' support for Viet Nam in the areas of governance and public administration reforms from citizens' perspective and experience 2) (Baseline 2009) No provinces have a citizen-centric measure to monitor their performance in local governance, public administration and public service delivery 3) (Baseline 2009) No evidence-based research assessing government performance in governance and public administration reforms from citizen experiences.

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2014 published and disseminated at the national level, involving a large diversity of stakeholders; the 2014 PAPI disseminated to provinces to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time in at least 7 provincial and regional workshops to disseminate PAPI 2014 convened for further policy dialogues with provinces during 2015 2) 19 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) responding to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance by end 2015 3) 21 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed by end 2015

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2014 published and disseminated at the national level, involving nearly 400 participants from different government and non-government sectors. 2014 PAPI findings also disseminated through: 8 regional workshops to show the progress of all 63 provinces in their government performance against 2011 baselines and over time; 3 training workshops to guide 120 elected representatives on how to use PAPI data as evidence for policy making and oversight work. Many provincial diagnostic workshops convened to have policy dialogues with provinces during 2015. 2) As of 1 Dec 2015, at least 25 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 21 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed by end 2015.

description.narrative: 1) Gaps between Viet Nam’s Legislation on Anti-corruption and UNCAC identified. 2) Number of policy researches and dialogues providing recommendations on transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in prevention of corruption and handling corruption cases 3) The extent to which concrete regulations on how to strengthen transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in handling corruption cases incorporated in the new/revised laws and other legal documents (0-not at all; 1- little; 2-significantly; 3-very significantly)

comment.narrative: 1) Some gaps already identified (i) no regulations on controlling corruption/bribery in the private sector; (ii) no regulations on controlling corruption involving foreign public officials; (iii) no regulations on controlling illicit enrichment; and (iv) no regulations on controlling corruption involving legal entities. 2) There is a lack of analysis and recommendation on how to strengthen transparent, integrated and well-coordinated mechanisms in preventing and handling corruption cases 3) 0-not at all. No recommendations incorporated, as none of them were available to policy makers

1) Further gaps identified in the criminal procedures for corruption crimes 2) At least one research on mechanisms to effectively control corruption crimes: international experience and lessons learnt for Viet Nam to provide inputs for the amendment of the Criminal Procedural Code 3) 2-significant. UNDP’s recommendations incorporated in draft Criminal Procedural Code and draft Law on Anti-corruption

description.narrative: Approval of regulations

comment.narrative: No regulations approved
By the end of year 4 of project implementation regulations have been formally issued (these regulations incorporate specific measures related to populations living within PAs)

Almost achieved.
The project has supported the development of the following regulations/legal documents:
1. Decision No 24 of Prime Minister on investment on special use forest, coming into effect on 20 July, 2012. The decision states that the government supports 40,000,000 vnd (2,000 USD) per hamlet in buffer zones per year to co-manage forest. Ministry of Planning and Investment led the development of this decision and the project supported by providing inputs and undertaking consultation to develop the Decision.
2. Inter-ministerial circular No. 160/TTLT-BTC-BTNMT between Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and Ministry of Finance on 19 Oct 2014 on biodiversity financing states that State budget can be allocated to develop biodiversity sustainable/wise use models in PAs. It creates an opportunity for local people to work with management boards and to receive budget from government to set up these kind of models.
3. Decision No. 119/QD-UBND on 23 Jan 2015 of Nam Dinh Provincial People Committee on sustainable mollusk harvesting. According to the Decision, local people have to pay a user fee to Xuan Thuy management board to engage in mollusk raising and management board has responsibility to guide them in techniques on sustainable mollusk raising. The amount as agreed by the local community, Xuan Thuy national park and the District People Committee is 2.000.000 vnd(98 USD)/ha/year.
4. Decision No. 2393/QD-UBND on 06 Nov 2014 of Lam Dong Provincial People Committee allows pilot Payments for Forest Ecosystem Services. Hydropower companies are required to pay the BD-NB management board an amount (around 150,000 USD) for forest protection per year. Part of this amount will be used to train local people in forest protection and afforestation.
5. Draft Decision of Hai Phong PPC allows pilot concessions in Cat Ba national park. This draft Decision was developed and circulated to related provincial departments for official comment. The final draft has been submitted to Hai Phong PPC for approval.

description.narrative: National PES policy identifies PES as one of the financing mechanisms for PAs

comment.narrative: Draft policy under development

The text of the PM's Decision on PES incorporates unambiguous wording establishing the basis for PAs to receive a significant proportion of PES funding for ecosystem services originating from land within the PA

Achieved
1. Decree No 99 of Government on Payment for Forest Ecosystem Services (PFES) policy identifies PFES as a financing mechanism for PAs.
2. Decision No 24 of Prime Minister on investment on special use forest encourages PES in PAs, especially ecotourism
3. Circular No. 20/2012/TT-BNNPTNT by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (7 May 2012) stipulates the provision of guidelines for procedures on confirmation and acceptance of monies payable for forestry ecosystem services
4. Inter-ministerial circular No. 160/TTLT-BTC-BTNMT on 29 Oct 2014 between MONRE and MOF allows using state budget to value ecosystem services and to enhance PES implementation.
The project has support to implement PES in demonstration sites as following: 1. In Xuan Thuy national park, the project has supported the park to develop a proposal on mollusk raising user fee collection and benefit sharing among stakeholders. 2. In Cat Ba national park, the project has supported the park to develop the proposal on increasing entrance fee and price for concession (hiring land to provide tourism services) 3. In Bidoup - Nui Ba national park, the project has supported the park to develop the proposal on increasing revenue from Payment for Forest Ecosystem Services

description.narrative: Establishment of a mechanism to promote coordination between MONRE and MARD

comment.narrative: No mechanism exists
By the end of year 2 of project implementation, a coordinating mechanism has been created by decree/decision

After discussion among UNDP, MONRE and MARD, it has been decided that the mechanism to promote coordination between MONRE and MARD is best agreed at the relevant agency level, in this case - Vietnam Environment Administration under MONRE and Vietnam Forest Administration under MARD. These two agencies are the administrations directly responsible for biodiversity conservation and protected area management within their respective Ministries. At 30 June, VEA, MONRE and VNFOREST, MARD were in the final stages of negotiating a Memorandum of Understanding.

description.narrative: Mechanism is operational

Achieved.
From Jun 2014 to Jun 2015: MONRE organized 12 training courses and MARD organized 13 training courses.
Total PAs participated in all 25 training courses are 97 PAs, representing 90.6% of all PAs (of the 107 PAs with established management boards). Of these, 83 PAs sent PA Directors/Vice Directors to attend the training, representing 77.5% of attendees.
In MTR report, it was proposed that the this indicator should be changed to "By the end of year 3 of project implementation, PA staff from at least 50% of PAs have been trained in key skills, such as business planning; by the end of the project this figure is 85%". The project has achieved this target.

description.narrative: This project aims to address these threats by increasing the resilience of infrastructure to climate change in the northern mountains.

title.narrative: Signed cover page of Project Document
Midterm Review for Promoting Climate Resilient Infrastructure in Northern Mountain Provinces of Vietnam

description.narrative: Support to enhance climate resilience of rural infrastructure interventions in northern provinces of Vietnam
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

To increase the resilience and reduce vulnerability of local, critical economic infrastructure in the northern mountains areas of Vietnam to the adverse impacts of climate change and to create a policy framework conducive to promoting resilient northern mountains zone development.
# of vulnerability maps presented and disseminated to % of Northern Mountain provinces.

comment.narrative: n/a – at project outset there is no vulnerability maps to disseminate

Detailed vulnerability maps for at least two northern mountainous provinces (a map for each province), with evidence that these have been presented and disseminated to at least 50% of Northern Mountain Provinces.

On track. Fifty percent completed. Vulnerability assessment results are nearly completed. The CPMU mobilized a firm and an international climate change expert in Quarter III 2014. An international climate change expert supported a national team to finalize the vulnerability assessment methodology introduced at the inception workshop (November 2013). A number of meetings with different institutions/ individuals were held, including a vulnerability assessment methodology consultation workshop in October 2014 to help finalize the methodology. After data collection and analysis, the consultant has submitted a complete database set and vulnerability assessment report to CPMU. Results were shared with Government stakeholders from 15 Northern mountain provinces and downscaled to two piloting provinces namely Backan and Sonla. This work will be further supported by the development of landslide and flashflood risk maps for the whole region and two provinces and will be completed in 2015. They are expected to provide visual vulnerability results based on different scenarios (AR-5, IPCC). This is a valuable opportunity for GoV to place in the public domain the extent of, and the spatial allocation of the likely public expenditures needed for resilience measures, and considered a key impact, as the baseline does not provide information on spatial variability of risk and vulnerability. As such, decision makers can recognize the vulnerabilities of their own provinces in comparison with other provinces. They may also learn how to cope with climate change from the provinces with same situation but higher coping capacities (less vulnerability). On the other hand and more importantly, they can use these maps as inputs for their rural infrastructure-related decisions, especially medium and long-termed planning. Achievements will be shared with Northern mountain provinces through relevant trainings at the end of 2015.

description.narrative: % of public expenditure directed towards the protection of rural infrastructure following the project guidance on climate resilient infrastructure.

comment.narrative: 0 funds invested
On 05 rural infrastructure projects, at least 5% additional public finance invested in infrastructure resilience, over and above SRID pilot demonstration.

On track. The vulnerability index and the hazard impact assessments will assist in the calculation of climate adaptation costs for rural infrastructure projects. The economic analysis team is working on this matter to introduce the formula and a number of case studies as examples. However, it is difficult to apply this formula under the SRIDP sub-projects because they have finished the sub-project screening, which requires economic analysis to be provided in advance. Hence the independent Midterm review team who were mobilized by UNDP-GEF in April suggest that CPMU, UNDP and MARD should discuss how to utilize this result in future projects. This issue might be brought to a PSC meeting which will be organized in late 2015 as expected. Currently, reviewing of the existing data/ situations/ documents/ etc. has finished and the second phase to deliver recommendations is well underway.
The following reports approved/ submitted: (i) policy (04 reports): Overview on existing policy and strategy related to rural infrastructure, Report of International good practices in policy and practice for climate resilient rural infrastructure, A thematic report on strengthening the resilience of rural infrastructure to climate change at international level, with focus on: (- Rural road infrastructure;- Rural water supply and irrigation; and, - River protection embankment); Thematic report on development of SEDP and agricultural and transportation sector plans in relation to rural infrastructure of the Northern mountain region; and (ii) economic analysis (02) cost-benefit analysis for climate proofing rural infrastructure projects, Report on Measures to quantify economic damages caused by CC on rural infrastructure in Northern mountain area; (iii) rural infrastructure engineering (5): The report on good international practice of engineering resilience in the context of rural roads, irrigation network and river embankments; Root cause analysis for losses and damages to the rural road infrastructure; Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the irrigation and river embankment infrastructure; The report on rural infrastructure vulnerability assessment to climate change for the Northern mountain provinces in Vietnam; Recommendations on integration of climate change adaptation into rural road investments; and Recommendations on integration of climate change into irrigation and embankment investments; (iv) vulnerability assessment report; (v) capacity strengthening: Report on climate change impacts on poverty reduction and socio-economic development in the northern mountain provinces; Report on the need of capacity strengthening on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces and Report on the capacity strengthening plan on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces.
A series of technical and progress meetings/ consultations/ field trips were held to improve the quality of the outputs and fasten the project progress with participation of various partners at different levels (community, district, province and central levels). Consulted institutions include (i) MARD - Directorate of Water Resources, Department of Construction Management, Department of Planning, Department of Science, Technology and Environment, Institute of Policy and Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development, Institute of Water Resources Planning; Disaster Management Center; New Rural Area Program Committee, Department of Dyke and Flood Protection, Vietnam Academy of Water Resources; National Institute of Agriculture Planning and Projection, Water Resources University, Institute of Water Resources Planning; (ii) MONRE - Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Climate change; Vietnam Institute of Geosciences and Mineral Resources, Institute of Geology; and Vietnam Department of Survey and Mapping; (iii) MOT - University of Transport; Transport Development and Strategy Institute; (iv) 15 project provinces and communes.

description.narrative: Climate Change Adaptation integrated into rural infrastructure (i.e. transport, irrigation, construction and water supply) strategies, policies, plans and regulations.
# of Technical papers providing guidance on mainstreaming climate change into sectorial planning related to rural infrastructure in northern areas.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been a guidance paper at project outset.
A Technical Guidance Paper on mainstreaming climate change into provincial rural infrastructure planning prepared by the project and circulated by MARD.

On track. The project successfully completed a comprehensive review of relevant policies that included a series of stakeholder consultations. Key findings include that most of MARD policies/ strategies do not take climate change into consideration and are not detailed enough for application. The need to employ pro-poor and no-regret approaches for resilience building were also clearly highlighted. The New Rural Development Program, Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program and provincial socio-economic development planning processes were particularly identified as priorities for further analysis and engagement by the project.
A policy consultation workshop at Thai Nguyen province on 9 September 2014 was able to solicit inputs from 11 departments/ institutes from MARD and MONRE and 14 DARDs. The meeting further highlighted the continued interest in learning from international experience in bio-engineering/ low-cost measures to support resilience.
A comprehensive review of current rural infrastructure planning, implementation and maintenance and field missions to discuss with key focal points, Government officials and community representatives highlighted a number of issues regarding low-cost measures including bio-engineering measures. The assessment included review of experience from 27 countries from the Netherlands to Laos with legal frameworks, codes and policies and implementation methods for introducing low-cost and bio-engineering options.
Analysis of the most recent climate change projections for Viet Nam and their potential impacts in the focus regions was also a key element of this work. With regards to the analysis of key hazards for the region, potential increases in intense and concentrated rainfall, and associated landslide risk, were highlighted as an issue in climate change projections that was particularly of concern with regards to rural infrastructure. Other factors impacting current resilience of infrastructure included poor designs, using unqualified materials, applying unsuitable technical solutions during construction process and O&M. The review also recognized the clear need to integrate climate change into existing relevant codes and standards, especially C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures which has been issued since 1970s. This implies that the vulnerability mapping under the project should take into account of above-mentioned climate disasters.
Key steps were also taken into initiating a review of current economic analysis practices and in starting to look at the economic consequences of climate change (losses). This work is likely to bolster the success of the project in suggesting appropriate methods, tools and procedures for climate proofing investment decision-making in the NMP. At a higher (Provincial) level, it is likely that a key tool for climate change adaptation investment guidance will continue to be the application of the MCA Multi Criteria Analysis method, as illustrated by the application of UNDP Teams integrated VA and Hazard models (which adopt an integrated format, in common with ICEM CAM methodology). As an example, work on the VA component has identified marked differences in Vulnerability between NMP provinces and ongoing work on Flood and Landslide Hazard risk is expected to further identify differences between provinces, which can assist to pinpoint the urgency and extent of CCA interventions (investments).
(To continue in General Comment box on Basic Data tab)

description.narrative: # of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

comment.narrative: n/a - at the project outset, there has not been a manual to guide mainstreaming of CC into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

02 manuals on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects (01 for rural roads and irrigation, and 01 for embankment) prepared by the project (taking into consideration of results of the demonstration projects) and circulated by MARD.

On track. The review phase indicates that although MARD has launched a lot of rural infrastructure projects, applied technical codes/ standards regarding rural roads come from MOT. However, Ministry of Transport has not really touched climate change adaptation in their projects/ planning/ codes/ standards. Hence, there is a need to improve existing code/ standards to consider climate resilience for these infrastructures. The review phase also revealed that it is not at all simple to insert project recommendations into existing codes/ standards of MOT since it is not only a long process but also requires inter-ministerial discussions. Despite such difficulties, some findings and recommendations mentioned in the report "Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the rural road infrastructure" have contributed to the draft manual of rural transport roads of the MOT. The contents inserted into the draft consist of (i) climate change impacts on rural roads; (ii) the importance of construction of drain structures; (iii) a number of feasible technical measures that can be applied; (iv) a number of pavements that can increase the resilience to climate change and (v) the importance of bio-engineering measures for slope protection. This can be seen as a great effort of the project already. Besides, the project has had similar contribution to the upgrading of two technical standards of MARD namely slope concrete standard and dam safety standard. The meetings with the two standard improvement teams have shown their high consensus in increasing the thickness of slope slabs to decrease the oxidation as consequence of extreme weather. Project recommendations have been appreciated and captured in the reports of standard improvement teams. Regarding the indicator of this outcome, to ensure the quality of UNDP's support to MARD, the MidTerm Review consultants suggest to change the indicator as "# of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects". Presently, consultant teams are working together to develop the manuals which are very coherent with each other (vulnerability index and Costs/Benefits calculation for instance). The methodologies to develop these manuals have been discussed with CPMU and UNDP based on the orientations/ expectations of the participants in the policy consultation workshop dated 29th May 2015. The expectations are mainly (i) a policy roadmap for MARD to adapt to climate change including possible technical standards; (ii) climate hazard risk maps and provincial planning based on these maps; (iii) low-cost and bio-engineering measures and (iv) related trainings. It is expected that first drafts of the manuals can be available in Quarter III/2015.

description.narrative: # of water resources standards and codes are informed to meet the requirements for climate resilience.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been any revision of water resources standards or codes.
By the end of the project at least 01 set of water resources standards informed by the project guidance.

On track with good progress. After a lot of consultations with both central and provincial levels showed that they all are very interested in upgrading codes/ standards or build a new set of standards to enable the application of new technologies or low-cost measures. Lack of these standards results in very time-consuming procedures in approval of bio-engineering interventions because MARD has no legal base for reference. This is also why demonstration subprojects managed by ADB have encountered a lot of difficulties regarding lack of related standards for their designs. Beside contributing to upgrading existing standards as mentioned in Indicator 2 of this Outcome, the project is (i) providing detailed recommendations on a key technical standard of Vietnam in irrigation named C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures and (ii) developing rural infrastructure engineering manuals which will provide s technical guidance for MARD to develop their own low-cost solution guidelines and then standards in near future. Consultations were held with the technical staff of the Department of Science, Technology and Environment (MARD) and Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology, Environment and Climate Change (MONRE) on updating C6-77. MARD is considering updating this standard in coming years, and the project will provide some initial support to MARD regarding this standard as their expectations. In 2015, the project expects to deliver specific recommendations by QIII and then consult again with MARD and related agencies regarding these recommendations. UNDP has also been working closely with the ADB component to help create a link between target sites and Government policy development regarding low-cost measures. Based on the designs, site visits, experience and lessons learnt and together with other feasible lessons, the technical team will develop detailed technical guidance documents of low-cost measures.
N/A

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity to adapt/climate-proof rural infrastructure investments and provincial/local area planning.
Coverage of Climate risks and vulnerability assessment.

comment.narrative: There has not been any climate vulnerability assessment implemented for rural infrastructure in Northern mountain provinces.
A climate risks and vulnerability assessment for rural infrastructure done for all 15 northern provinces.

On track. As reported above, the assessment will cover 15 project provinces including Dien Bien, Lai Chau, Son la, Hoa Binh, Vinh Phuc, Phu Tho, Bac Giang, Bac Kan, Yen Bai, Lao Cai, Lang Son, Cao Bang, Thai Nguyen, Tuyen Quang and Ha Giang, then downscaled to Son La and Backan. After the vulnerability assessment methodology approved, the contractor sent their teams to all provinces and then all districts of two demonstration provinces as named above Son La and Backan to collect secondary data and interviews for missing data (O&M data). The types of structures under the assessment consist of (i) rural roads; (ii) river embankments; (iii) weirs; (iv) reservoirs and (v) main canals that are classified as categorical and continuous. The process tracks the following indicators: age of works, number of communes cut off from main road per year, past damages, number of secondary structures on road, material of road/ embankment, O&M, ratio of poor households, proportion of minorities, proportion of working age population, community contribution to infrastructure, number of site inspection, type of construction codes followed, number of times of damages, number of reservoirs stopped from functioning. Weightings are also laid for each kind of these indicators.Results show a picture of Son La, Backan and Ha Giang as the most vulnerable province in terms of risk. These results will be further deepened with specific recommendations provided by the project in the remaining time of the year. The next step will be to integrate these maps with future climate change projects.

description.narrative: # of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been any rural infrastructure plan that is developed based on climate risk and vulnerability assessment.
At least two (02) provincial plans/strategy per target province (Son La and Bac Kan) guided as results of the project climate risks and vulnerability assessments, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

"Major planning decisions being modified due to vulnerability maps (in 2 target provinces)" indicator should be changed into "# of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC", which reflects better the influences of the project on the provinces because the project can only suggest the provinces to use the outputs. To date, climate risk and vulnerability maps have been provided to all target provinces for use in planning. Two PPCs (Backan and Sonla) have expressed their willingness to apply project recommendations into their investment plans. A provincial strategy expert who is being under recruitment of CPMU will take this work forward.
A team of provincial strategy development is under recruitment of CPMU. They will be mobilized in August as expected for review of existing provincial action plans and then recommend appropriate adjustments. If mapping packages can happen as expected, this team can take use of the maps for their recommendation report. Generally speaking, this activity is on track with a risk as indicated above.

description.narrative:
Level of capacity of provincial leaders to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning enhanced
% of technical personnel having ability to apply risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes

comment.narrative:
At the project outset, evaluated scores of management personnel in the 15 Northern provinces are as follows:
Institutional capacity on climate change adaptation (CCA) = 1.43/5
Organizational and planning capacity on CCA =1.71/5; and
Technical capacity on CCA = 1.78/5
Risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning is not yet available in Vietnam.

By the end of the project, capacity of provincial decision makers (DARD, DPI, DOT, DONRE) to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning in the 15 northern mountainous provinces is at least (40%) higher than the project baseline;
Up to 120 technical personnel from the 15 Northern provinces trained in CCA related issues and at least 50% of them having technical capability in applying climate risks and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes.

On track with delay. This activity has started slower than the others because trainings had to be developed based on project results. Mobilized in Quarter II/2014, the capacity strengthening expert completed a capacity strengthening assessment focusing on institutional, organizational and technical capacities. These results reflect the baseline of the project. The assessment indicated a high level of demand for in improving the local capacity for climate change adaptation. In response to this, the project has decided to increase the number of training events by 40% Provincial stakeholders had a chance ot contribute to the design of the training programme through two consultation meetings. Trainings will focus on 04 topics namely (i) Policy for climate change resilience for senior provincial officials; (ii) Vulnerability assessment as a tool to increase climate change resilience for technical officers; (iii) Integrating climate change resilience into annual planning and prioritization and (iv) Training skills about climate change adaptation for provincial officials. As such, the details on vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure planning will bee transferred in (ii) and (iii). Target trainees include leaders and technical/ planning staff of 04 relevant provincial departments including Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Department of Transport, Department of Natural Resources and Environment and Department of Planning and Investment from 15 beneficiary provinces. Trainers will be project experts or outsourced from professional agencies such as Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Climate Change. There will be a total of 12 classes for 04 mentioned topics targeted to senior and technical level staff. Around 120 government personnel ware expected to be trained.

description.narrative: Effective climate-resilience measures mainstreamed into rural infrastructure programs.

The approaches developedâ€”including promising modifications, alternatives, and lessons learnedâ€”will be utilized by MARD rural infrastructure investments as standard practice in 100% of new ADB-financed projects by month 36.

comment.narrative: MARD has mainstreamed low cost climate measures for cross drainage structures by the use of drifts but not other measures.
1. Documentation identifying low cost climate proofing suitable for rural infrastructure in northern Viet Nam completed
There are no demonstrations of appropriate climate resilience techniques for rural infrastructure.
2. Demonstrations are successfully completed on four SRIDP subprojects by month 24.
3. Training carried out for 60 (â‰¥40% female) DARD staff from the 15 project provinces by month 34.
4. Recommendations completed and issued to the relevant institutions by month 34
5. Assessments for strengthening the climate resilience of the communities near the four subproject areas completed by month 30

description.narrative: Lessons learnt and best practices from Outcomes 1, 2 and 3 are disseminated to stakeholders and development partners
# of Project lessons and best practices captured, classified and evaluated;

comment.narrative: No project lessons learnt published by the project at the project outset

At least 08 articles/video clips/leaflets published by the end of the project
At least two (02) peer technical papers reviewed by the end of the project to facilitate professional discussion and advocacy

On track. Most of communication products will come at the final phase of the project to introduce project outputs. However, after the review phase, there were some articles published on websites/ magazines to (i) emphasize the necessity of climate adaptation in existing legal documents or (ii) draw attention to a number of technical adaptation measures. Articles published include: (1) “Integration of climate adaptation into relevant policy regarding water resources structures in Northern mountain region” published in Water Resources magazine in April 2015; (2) An article on the vulnerability assessment methodology workshop was published on 27th October 2014 by the Vietnam Science and Technology magazine (3) “Non-structural measures to protect slop at Northern Mountain region” by Mr. Hoang Tuan, Vice Director of Department of Construction Management (MARD) was published in on the VNCOLD website (Vietnam National Committee of Large Dams and Water Resources Development). Additional articles are under draft. The CPMU is recruiting a communication specialist who will help to capture project lessons, share experience through articles or videos.

description.narrative: Level of CCA knowledge and experiences documented and disseminated within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond

comment.narrative: 0 contributions.

Started. Project deliverables will be documented and shared within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond. It is expected that there will be low-cost measures documented to become manuals. Besides, future projects may also learn from both negative and positive lessons gained through a project management report. All of these products are under development and can be available in next year, 2016.

title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity in Climate Change in Industry

description.narrative: The project is to encourage industry to invest in low carbon technologies and more resource efficient practices through policy and regulatory measures and by directly supporting market participants and energy service providers.

The project is to encourage industry to invest in low carbon technologies and more resource efficient practices through policy and regulatory measures and by directly supporting market participants and energy service providers.
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity

- Number of policy and market barriers to industry pursuing sustainable investments and number of options for policy makers and industry stakeholders to overcome barriers - Number of policy measures (new or revised) developed that incentivize industry to reduce GHG emissions and/or increase resilience to potential climate change impacts - Number of systems in MOIT identified to improve monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of GHG emissions, including institutions, information and awareness material, staff training programs and data collection and analysis processes - Number of trainers trained on sustainable industrial production, number of hits on project website, number of stakeholders from target sub-sectors attending workshops and training - Number of specialized financial products available in target industry sub-sectors - Number of service providers active in the market in target industry sub-sectors and number of new business models developed

comment.narrative: - Lack of systematic and analytical approaches in MOIT to identify policy and market barriers to reduce GHG emissions and enhance climate resilience. - The Government committed to develop green growth policies, but current laws have limited reflection of climate change considerations, such as resource efficiency, cleaner production and sustainable consumption. - Systems to accurately monitor GHG emissions are in their early stages of establishment at the national level but GHG emissions are monitored only on an ad hoc basis in the industry sector. - Market opportunities for investment in sustainable production are not aware by service providers, financial institution and industrial enterprises - Private finance is not readily available for investments in sustainable industrial production - There are currently around 25 energy service providers active in the industry sector, most of which are government owned Energy Service Centres. Only one private energy service provider is operating on a commercial basis

title.narrative: Legal Empowerment through Support VN Lawyers Association

description.narrative: Legal Empowerment through Support for the Vietnam Lawyers Association
The Project aims to support Vietnam Lawyers' Association (VLA) and civil society organizations in promoting legal empowerment for the poor in Viet Nam.
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

1) Quality of data collection and policy-oriented research and law submissions by the Viet Nam Lawyers' Association (VLA) and civil society organizations (CSOs) to the Government and National Assembly (1 - very poor; 2 - relatively good; 3 - good; 4 - very good). 2) Number of the poor and disadvantaged in the target regions being aware of their rights and benefiting from access to the VLA Legal Consultancy Centers (LCCs) and legal aid service. 3) Availability of mechanism for partnership and collaboration between VLA and other social organizations/CSOs to address social justice.

comment.narrative: 1) 1-very poor. Very limited capacity of the Viet Nam Lawyers' Association (VLA) in policy submission and legislation due to lack of a systematic data collection and analysis. Limited capacity of the VLA in empirical research and data collection to support its policy and law-reform recommendations. 2) Small number of people assisted by the VLA's Legal Consultancy Centers due to the constrained resource and the lack of innovation in their outreach program and service delivery method. 3) Mechanism for partnership and collaboration between the VLA and local NGOs, CSOs on addressing social injustice does not exist.

1) 4-very good quality of data collection and law submissions though continuous support to VLA, with focus on the development of a new instrument for citizen's voice on the administration of justice (entitled "Justice Index in 2015". 2) At least 8,000 poor people benefited by VLA legal aid 3) The model of VLA-local NGO partnership that was experimented in 2014 will be further expanded to address social injustices, to advance legal empowerment of the poor, and to advocate for creating an enabling environment for CSOs through multiple grants to VLA-CSO partnership and at the structural level, to development of a Law on Association in Viet Nam

1) 4-very good. Data collection for the Justice Index completed in December, giving voice to more than 13,600 person nationwide. Three law submissions and proposals for law amendments were submitted to the National Assembly with UNDP support, including the Law on Referendum, the revised Law on Administrative Litigation, the revised Law on Temporary Custody and Detention. 2) More than 8,000 people benefited by the VLA legal aid. 3) The partnership model continues to improve - three joint initiatives were granted and contributed to addressing prioritized demand for justice at grass-root level.

description.narrative: The project is to provide technical assistance and capacity development support to achieve the government's accelerated poverty reduction targets in the poorest ethnic minority, mountainous and coastal areas.

policy, planning and administration

1) Number of PR policies streamlined/harmonized/mainstreamed into the regular plans and policy framework of line ministries, following concrete guidelines from the Resolution 80 and its Action Plan 2) Extent to which the program document and guidelines for implementation and management of the harmonized NTP-SPR reflect the application of PR innovative modalities and block grant model (1-No progress: no consideration, 2-In progress: good practices in innovation and block grant model discussed and considered in different policy dialogues, 3-Good progress: policy recommendations taken/integrated in newly issued or revised policy documents), 3) Degree to which empowerment is executed and extent to which multi-dimensional needs of chronic poor people, including poor women, ethnic minority people are met during the implementation of the NTP-SPR (1. No progress: no consideration, 2. In progress: good practices in innovation and block grant model discussed and considered in different policy dialogues, 3. Good progress: policy recommendations taken/integrated in newly issued or revised policy documents),

comment.narrative: 1) 40 poverty reduction policies and programs exist in a fragmented way and sometimes are designed in an ad-hoc manner, though the Resolution 80 already defined directions for streamlining and mainstreaming of poverty reduction policies and harmonizing national poverty reduction program. 2) 1-No progress. Community-based participatory planning and budgeting models available in 28 provinces but not yet institutionalized. 3) 1-No progress. Available tools for poverty monitoring are income based, despite a commitment of Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA) on development of a road-map for multi-dimensional poverty and emerging vulnerability monitoring and analysis.

1) 16 national targeted programs harmonized/consolidated into 2 national targeted programs; 3 education policies harmonized/consolidated into one. 2) 2-In progress. NTP- SPR 2016-2020 formulated in a consultative and harmonized process, based on the good practices and innovative models promoting resource integration, community empowerment and enhanced people's participation. 3) 3-Good progress. MDP Master Plan approved by the Prime Minister, with actions to address multidimensional needs of the poor.

1) 16 targeted programs consolidated into 2 national targeted programs (NTPs): (i) National Assembly Resolution 100/2015/QH13 on investment of two NTPs, (ii) a draft policy by Ministry of Education and Training, replacing 3 education support policies. Importantly, UNDP enabled the issuance of the Govt’s MDG accelerated targets and action plan for Ethnic Minority (MAP-EM). The Viet Nam’s MDG acceleration targets is the first in the world attempt to go beyond addressing the unfinished MDGs at the national averages to addressing the unfinished MDGs among specific population groups. This contributed to the recognition of EM groups’ lagging behind as a national priority and directed NTPs to focus on them. 2) 2-in progress. UNDP‘s work led to the adoption (i) by MPI, MOLISA, MARD and CEMA, the harmonization in the design of the NTP-SPR, with focus on improving community ownership as evidenced in the NA Resolution 100 on NTPs, and (ii) by CEMA and 8 provinces, of the social anthropological approaches in policy formulation and practice of participatory planning. These contributed to (i) improvements in the national PR program’s identifying needs of the EM and meeting these needs, (ii) proposal of the ministries for improving people participation and community empowerment toward a self-help and inclusive community development approach in the design of two NTPs 2016-2020 targeting the poorest communities. 3) 3-Good progress. Viet Nam Govt adopted multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) approach under the Prime Minister’s Decision No.1614/QĐ-Ttg. This MDP Master plan guides the national poverty reduction programming and targeting for 2016-2020. The adoption of MDP recognizes both income and non-income deprivations of the poor, including ethnic minority poor. It also means 2% of Viet Nam’s households (2.5 million people) that are not income poor but suffer from 3 or more non-income deprivations are eligible for GOVN’s poverty reduction programs and policies.
