1) Number of accompanying Decrees and legal documents developed and issued to support the promulgation of the Disaster Risk Management Law 2) Number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) policies, strategies and legislation revised to: - Embrace and keep track of changing dynamics of DRR, CCA and CC impacts; - Integrate gender equity and differing needs of vulnerable groups 3) Improvement of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - % completion of capacity building activities planned in the project. - Number of direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The increasing of overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) Number of targeted vulnerable communes/wards have CBDRM plan of action developed under the CBDRM Programme 5) Number of “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1) Zero. By end of 2011, Version 3 of the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) Law was circulated to Ministries and for public consultation. A first draft of the accompanying Decree was produced 2) Zero. The existing overall disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) framework, though comprehensive, not yet reflecting the national, regional and international context and impacts of climate change, neither integrating gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups 3) Overall capacity scorecard of CCFSC was 2.2 points out of 5 points (2013) 4) None. 5) None. “Building blocks” are in the final stage of development, not yet rolled out.

1) No additional legal document, but interim target is: at least 01 study to provide inputs for initiating and sustaining a financial mechanism for DRM Law (specifically the Decree on Disaster Prevention Fund). 2) All relevant key technical papers initiated in 2015 address changing dynamics of DRR, CCA, CC impacts, and reflect gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups. 3) At least 300 CCFSC officials have improved knowledge on: - Damage and Need assessment; - Risk assessment; - Extreme flood and super-storm risk management 4) At least 250 new communes have their local CBDRM plan of actions developed 5) Development of an additional “building block” for the CBDRM programme financing reviewed (for future re - approval in 2016)

1) No additional legal document, but very good progress: - The initial analysis of CBDRM financing conducted and presented at mid-term review. - A study on sustainable funding strategy for DRM in line with the Law under draft and expected to be finalized in 2016. 2) Completed: - Draft Action Plan developed in partnership with World Bank - The draft Action Plan to implement the National Strategy on DRM. 3) 320 CCFSC staff (34% are women) have improved knowledge and skills on: - Damage and Need assessment; - Risk assessment; - Extreme flood and super-storm risk management 4) More than 250 (estimated 270) communes developed CBDRM plan of actions and conduct activities according to developed plans under the 1002 Programme. 5) Supported development of a Circular on CBDRM implementation expected to be approved in early 2016. Foundation study for the development of the additional “building block” under draft, however completion of building block may be delayed due to changes in Government systems. In total however 6/7 building blocks are now in place.

title.narrative: Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban

description.narrative: Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban areas.
Support to multi-dimensional poverty reduction in urban settings.
seat of a first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

1) Availability of multi-dimensional poverty (MDP) measures and level of institutionalization of the measures in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC) 2) Availability of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Number of evidence-based and participatory policies developed/revised/improved to address multi-dimensional poor and to ensure equal access to services 4) The availability of new and creative tools to address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) The extent to which HCMC’s experience is shared with and applied by other provinces

comment.narrative: 1) Multi-dimensional poverty measures do not exist in Ho Chi Minh city (HCMC). Poverty status is monitored based on a monetary approach 2) There is a lack of multi-dimensional and in-depth analyses on poverty status for evidence-based and participatory policy making 3) Very few evidence-based and participatory policies that address multi-dimensional poverty, despite the fact that HCMC population is still suffering from many deficiencies, such as social security, housing, health care, and education, etc. 4) No tools specifically address urban poverty following multi-dimensional approach. 5) No province being shared or applying the same methodologies and tools, though MOLISA at the central level plans to develop action plans for implementing the Government’s Resolution 80B on poverty reduction following the multi-dimensional approach.

1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting finalized and institutionalized 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot completed and shared with wide stakeholders; Research report on actual situation on urbanization and urban management in Viet Nam and in HCMC, suggesting options and actions for improvement 3) Two groups of policy developed based on the MDP approach: (i) Poverty reduction policies reviewed, developed and piloted in a number of HCMC’s localities, tailored to specific needs of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders; and (ii) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 4) Policy pilots implemented, providing experience and recommendations for scaling up; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; Prioritized groups for poverty reduction identified 5) HCMC’s MDP progress and experience widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces

1) MDP measures, data collection procedure for monitoring, listing and targeting officially approved by HCMC People's Council for application in HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme 2) Consolidated report on 2013 MDP Pilot, Urban Poverty Report 2012, and 4 working papers on MDP analysis, policy suggestions, and data collection models completed and shared with wide stakeholders; 3) HCMC's 2016-2020 Sustainable Poverty Reduction Programme developed with the official application of MDP approach and method. A relevant detailed policy framework is being developed and tailored to address specific deprivations of prioritized groups, integrated into SEDPs and sectoral plans, and well-coordinated and monitored by different stakeholders. 4) A number of policy interventions and coordination improvements implemented, providing experience and recommendations for developing the detailed policy framework for HCMC's new sustainable poverty reduction programme in 2016-2020; MDP indicators and non-registered migrants included into VHLSS for MDP monitoring; 5 prioritized groups for poverty reduction have been officially identified for relevant supports. 5) A "South-South Exchange Workshop on addressing MDP and improving Service Delivery" co-organized by UNDP Viet Nam (in coordination with UNDP BRH) and HCMC to share and exchange HCMC experience with 6 countries and OPHI. HCMC’s MDP progress and experience also widely shared and consulted with central and local policy makers, researchers, etc. through various advocacy and media events, workshops for sharing experience, identifying areas for cooperation, planning future roadmap with other provinces (Da Nang, Vung Tau, KonTum, etc.).

description.narrative: Support to implementation of Vietnam Statistical Development Strategy 2011-2020, Vision to 2030
Support to Implementation of Vietnam Statistical Development Strategy 2011-2020, Vision to 2030
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity

1) Compatibility of the revised Statistics Law and under-law documents with official statistical principles (UNSD), with the focus on ensuring (i) collection of objective, reliable and timely data, (ii) users’ transparent access to data 2) Availability and actual operation of new organizational structures, regulations, mechanisms, and tools to serve data sharing (i) within GSO; (ii) among main data producers/providers in the VSS and between those main data producers/providers with GSO; and (iii) with data users. 3) Level of satisfaction of data users related to (i) accessibility; (ii) quality; and (iii) timeliness of statistical data released by GSO. 4) Quality of national accounts data and users’ satisfaction of national accounts data (Scale: 1- poor; 2-relatively good; 3-good; 4-very good) 5) Timeliness and usefulness of information and data to measure progress against objectives, to identify difficulties to be addressed in a timely manner, and to draw lessons in the implementation of VSDS, and its action plans (Scale: 1-poor; ; 2-relatively good; 3-good; 4-very good)

comment.narrative: 1) Legal framework (the Statistics Law 2003 and under-law documents) for statistical activities is not adequate/does not ensure official statistical principles (UNSD) and overlaps, which causes difficulties for implementation; 2) Inefficient organizational structures, lack of regulations/policies/ mechanisms and tools for data sharing, poor compliance of the statistical legislation, lack of sanctions, etc., causing poor implementation of the reporting system between ministries/agencies and GSO/PSOs, insufficient and limited sharing of primary data even among GSO departments, inconsistent data sources, and confusions and reduction of trust by data users. 3) The satisfaction level with disseminated statistical information by data users was at 31.3% in 2008 (GSO’s survey, 2008). 4) 1-poor. The reasons include: Limited knowledge of sectoral and provincial statistical reporting systems of statistical staff in ministries and provinces is still limited; Lack of information needed for the aggregation of National accounts indicators. 5) 1-poor, though a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework of the implementation of VSDS issued by Ministry of Planning and Investment (GSO).

1) Final draft of Revised Statistics Law and Decree is in compatibility with official statistical principles (UNSD), especially in ensuring (i) collection of objective, reliable and timely data, (ii) users’ transparent access to data. 2) Regulations and mechanisms on data sharing further developed, including: (i) Project on "Improvement of state management of statistical data quality" completed and approved by MPI for implementation; (ii) A strategy for Viet Nam Statistical System’s integration into ASEAN for the period 2016-2020 endorsed by the Prime Minister which is the basis for comprehensive integration in statistics field; and (iii) A web-based software for online M&E of VSDS implementation for ministries and provinces developed and used. 3) Increased level of users’ satisfaction 4) 3-good. This can be achieved through: (i) A roadmap for implementation of GRDP project endorsed by the Prime Minister; and (ii) A macroeconomic analysis based on the updated Input-Output tables 5) 3-good. This can be achieved through a mid-term review of the VSDS implementation

1) The Statistics Law 2015 approved by the National Assembly in November and launched in December with the integration of National Statistics Indicators for SDGs monitoring and evaluation. A decree on implementation guidance of the Law is being developed. 2) The project on "Improvement of state management of statistical data quality" is being finalized for approval by MPI for implementation; 3) Data not available to measure the achievement of this target 4) 3-good. A roadmap for implementation of GRDP project endorsed by the Prime Minister; A macroeconomic analysis based on the updated Input-Output tables has been completed and widely shared with users. 5) 3-good. The mid-term review of VSDS implementation is being implemented and will be finished by early 2016 to draw lessons learnt, to identify bottlenecks and to suggest sollutions and renovations in implementing the VSDS for the coming half of the whole implementation period 2011-2020.

comment.narrative: 1) 1-very poor. Viet Nam is increasingly engaging with human rights mechanisms but the level of awareness and capacity on HR reporting is very poor. 2) 1-very poor. Coordinated and high quality human rights reporting as well as generating human rights data and information is still a big challenge inhibiting the development and implementation of targeted human rights policies in VN; the UPR process is still relatively new and being improved, guidance is needed on how to effectively compile and present the UPR report; Viet Nam is considering ratification of other core human rights treaties 3) Very few policy-oriented research in human rights. Human rights research is very ad hoc and does not focus on topics that are vital for the development of key government human rights policies; access to research products is still limited mostly to research institutions, uncoordinated and not linked to or providing reference for government agencies.

1) 3-Good level of awareness and capacity of Government officers to be achieved, through continued support with focus on implementation of UPR Action Plan, and CRPD and CAT reporting. 2) 3-Good level of treaty reporting's process and coordination, through support to establish an inter-ministerial reporting coordination group for data collection and monitoring. 3) One research on CRPD statistical gap to be conducted for recommendations to greater compliance in CRPD reporting.

1) 3-Good. Increased awareness of policy offers on CAT obligations and their implications to behavior changes and practices. Increased awareness of state officers across Government agencies on UPR commitments and the follow-up Action Plan. 2) 3-Good. CAT and CRPD data gap analysis has started and will be continued in 2016. Primary meeting of an inter-ministerial coordination group for human rights was organized. The UPR Action Plan approved by Prime Minister as results of cross-agency coordination led by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 3) Research on CRPD statistical gap is commissioned, results will be published in 2016.

description.narrative: - Number of CSOs received training on management, leadership, human rights programming, networking and advocacy. - Number of study conducted that identifies stigma and discrimination faced by LGBT. - Number of laws, policies drafted that relate to LGBT rights.

comment.narrative: In recent years, there has been more openness in Viet Nam to address the rights of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) communities. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) have had greater visibility as they reach out to the public, media have reported positive messages on the issues faced by the LGBT community, and institutions within the government and National Assembly have increasingly invited representatives of the LGBT community to discuss same-sex marriage and other issues affecting the community. Although LGBT are not criminalized, they still face severe stigma and discrimination at individual, family and community levels, which impedes their access to health and social services and at times negatively impacts their education and employment opportunities. This project intends to address these gaps. - 28 CSOs are working on LGBT issues across the country, with varying degree of capacities on managing CSOs. - Lack of a comprehensive research in the country on stigma and discrimination faced by LGBT, in particular on stigma and discrimination faced at health and educational facilities and in the work place. - Few LGBT CSOs engaged in dialogue with the government.

description.narrative: 1. M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy and Action Plan 2. Guideline on green growth investment. 3. Guideline for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plan. 4. Number of sectoral and provincial GG action plans with GHG emission targets. 5. Communication action plan, and number of events and media coverage. 6. Number of policy studies and dialogues relating to green investments, green transportation, green procurement and financial tools for green development. 7. Level of availability of financial data and information to interested stakeholders. 8. Number of report on climate public and private expenditures. 9. Number of green growth projects ideas and proposals.

comment.narrative: 1. M& E mechanism is not in place. 2. No guideline is in place. 3. No guideline is in place. 4. No GG action plan has been formulated for target sectors and provinces. 5. Communication action plan is not in place. 6. Limited studies have been produced by other development partners. 7. A UNDP-WB supported website in place and some scattered information in various websites. 8. No report on climate finance expenditures produced; 9. No green growth projects ideas and proposals by businesses in place

1. The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy drafted 2. Not a target for 2015, for it is for 2016. 3. Guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans approved. 4. Two provincial Green Growth action plans with GHG emission reduction targets formulated. 5. Not a target for 2015, it is for 2016. 6. Five report of studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development, prepared. 7. Not a target for 2015, it is for 2016 and 2017 8. One report on national climate public expenditure and investment review completed and launched. 9. Not a target for 2015; it is for 2016, 2017, and 2018

1. The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy prepared and will be finalized in early 2016. 2. NA, as no target was set for 2015 3. A national guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans prepared and awaiting for approval by MPI. 4. Quang Ninh Green Growth Action Plan approved in Nov 2015 and Green Growth Action Plan of Da Lat city finalized and pending for a formal approval. 5. NA, as no target was set for 2015 6. Five reports prepared and will be finalized in early 2016.. 7. NA, as no target was set for 2015 8. Report on national climate public expenditure and investment review completed and launched in May 2015. 9. NA, as no target was set for 2015
